#Text=Mérida
#Text=Mérida is the capital of the state of Yucatán in Mexico .
#Text=It has a population of about 750,000 , and is the largest city in the Yucatán Peninsula .
#Text=Catedral de San Ildefonso
#Text=Zócalo or Main Plaza , with the Cathedral in the distance
#Text=Understand
#Text=Mérida is a city of contrasts .
#Text=You will find elegant hotels , restaurants and malls in the northern part of the city .
#Text=Downtown , there are hotels and restaurants to suit every budget .
#Text=A large central market and numerous small shops are found all around the main plaza .
#Text=Mérida has a rich cultural life which also reflects its diversity .
#Text=Many free concerts , performances and other events are held daily .
#Text=The city was founded by the Spanish conquistadors in the 1540s on top of a centuries - old Maya city called T'ho .
#Text=The palatial home of the family of conquistador leader Montejo can still be seen on the south side of the Zócalo or main square .
#Text=Here and there bits of ancient Maya stonework can be seen reused in Spanish Colonial era buildings in the old part of town .
#Text=From the later 1800s to the 1920s Mérida enjoyed prosperous boom times fueled by the henequen or sisal plant harvest , which made Yucatán the rope maker to the world .
#Text=Progressive Mérida had electric trams and street lights before Mexico City .
#Text=The wealthy constructed the grand Pasejo Montejo avenue north of the old town , inspired by the Champs - Élysées in Paris .
#Text=With the development of artificial twines the sisal boom ended , and Mérida slowed to a more sleepy provincial capital until development picked back up in the late 20th century .
#Text=The city 's ambiance is colonial and the climate is tropical .
#Text=The daytime temperature varies ; in January , it is about 24 ° C ( 75 ° F ) and in June , about 35 ° C ( 95 ° F ) .
#Text=To beat the heat , most people are busiest in the mornings .
#Text=They have lunch and siesta , then go back to work for a few hours in the late afternoon .
#Text=The cool breezes from the Gulf of Mexico drift into Mérida in the evenings and this is when many of the residents spend their time outdoors .
#Text=You can see them visiting and talking as they stroll along the streets , sit in the plazas or dine in the many sidewalk restaurants .
#Text=From Mérida , it is easy to take day trips to a vast array of destinations : archaeological sites , ecological parks , typical villages , caves , beaches , colonial missions and more .
#Text=Take your time and really explore the Maya sites , walk for miles along the Gulf of Mexico , attend a village festival , photograph the wildlife , crawl through a cave or swim in a cenote .
#Text=Tourist Information ( Turismo Mérida ) , email : turismo@merida.gob.mx .
#Text=The city maintains several tourist information offices , all of which can offer helpful information on accommodation , free maps , and bus connections .
#Text=All offices also have free copies of Yucatan Today , a helpful weekly Spanish - English publication listing all events in the city and the surrounding region .

#Text=City Hall Information Center ( Módulo de Información Turística Palacio Municipal ) Calle 62 between 61 and 63 ( inside the Palacio del Gobierno left of the main entrance ) , ☎ + 529999420000 x 80119 .
#Text=Paseo de Montejo Information Module ( Módulo de Información Turística Paseo de Montejo ) Ave Paseo de Montejo 56A x 33A ☎ + 529999204044 e-mail : turismo@merida.gob.mx .
